User Workflow

Once you have set up your environment and project databases have been created (usually by an Administrator), you can perform daily version control tasks such as:

  • Opening a project database, which contains projects and files under version control.
  • Setting a workspace to specify the directory from which you check in files and to which you check out files.
  • Getting a revision of a versioned file without locking it.
  • Checking out a revision of a versioned file for editing, which locks it so that others cannot overwrite your changes.
  • Checking in the workfile, which creates a new revision.

Occasionally, you'll need to place additional folders and files under source control. You can do this by selecting a project database or project and then:

  • Adding files, which allows you to add workfiles or entire directories (and subdirectories). If you're adding directories, projects (and subprojects) are created automatically with names mirroring the directory structure. Archives are created for each workfile you add.
  • Creating a project, which allows you to group related files or specify a name other than the directory you're adding.
